name: Ross Anderson
background: Cambridge professor, author of 'Security Engineering'. Studies economics of security, why security fails in practice. Pioneer of security economics and usable security.

principles.name: Security fails because incentives are misaligned
principles.description: Technical security often fails for economic reasons. Those who could fix vulnerabilities don't bear the costs of failure. Align incentives before adding technology.
principles.falsification: When technical measures succeed despite misaligned incentives

principles.name: Complexity is the enemy of security
principles.description: Every additional feature is an attack surface. Simple systems are easier to secure and verify. Reduce complexity before adding security controls.
principles.falsification: When added complexity enables defense-in-depth that outweighs attack surface increase

principles.name: The weakest link determines security
principles.description: Attackers target the easiest path, not the hardest. A system's security equals its weakest component. Uniform security levels matter more than peaks of strength.
principles.falsification: When defense-in-depth means attackers must breach multiple independent barriers
